entry.dc:subject: blogging
entry.content:
... durch die deutsche Blogwelt.

Grund ist das Produkt IzyNews, der belgischen Firma IzySoft. Dieses versucht, die vielen Feed-Quellen des Internets dem Otto-Normal-Anwender zugänglich zu machen. Dafür bietet es einen kostenpflichtigen Abo-Service an, der RSS-Feeds per IMAP zur Verfügung stellt (es gibt auch ein kostenloses Mini-Abo, das auf 20 Feeds beschränkt ist). Soweit, so gut.

Allerdings sehen sich viele deutsche Blogger darin eine Verletzung ihrer, meist die kommerzielle Verwendung ausschliessende, Lizenzvereinbarungen, unter welche sie ihre Inhalte stellen. Manche greifen schnell zur technologischen Schrotflinte und sperren IzyNews aus. Andere hingegen bevorzugen einen anderen Weg, und wollen IzyNews mit "konventionellen" Mitteln daran hindern ihre Inhalte zu aggregieren und dabei kommerziell zu nutzen.

Markus hat sich über diese Sache, wie üblich, ein wenig grundsätzlicher Gedanken gemacht, und ist dabei im Gegensatz zu vielen anderen herrlich unaufgeregt. Er fragt sich unter anderem, und das auch nicht zum ersten Mal, ob diese ganze Aufregerei "typisch deutsch" (seine Worte) ist. Ich denke "Ja" und "Nein".

Wenn ich ausdrücklich sage, dass niemand ausser mir mit meinen Blog-Texten Geld verdienen darf, und dieser Wunsch bzw. diese Einschränkung wird einfach übergangen, dann würde ich mich auch aufregen. Soviel zum "Nein".

Allerdings sollte man sich schon mal fragen, wem es denn wirklich weh tut, dass jemand Feeds in einem anderen Medium verbreitet, und sie damit evtl. einer grösseren Leserschaft zur Verfügung stellt, und dafür Geld verlangt. Wer von den Bloggern, die sich so herrlich aufregen, verdient denn soviel Geld mit seinem Bloggen, dass ein Anbieter wie IzyNews, ihnen Geld wegnimmt?

IzyNews wechselt nur die Zugangstechnologie (Feed2Email) und bietet seinen Nutzern durch Vorselektion/Filtern von Feeds einen evtl Nutzen, wenn auch meiner Meinung nach einen sehr fragwürdigen. Und dafür verlangt es Geld. Schön für IzyNews wenn Menschen dafür bezahlen wollen. Schön für die Blogger, wenn sich dadurch ihre Reichweite vergrössert (schön in diesem Zusammenhang ist Moes Frage). Also sollte man doch meinen, dass IzyNews sowas wie eine Win-Win-Situation darstellt. Offensichtlich sehen manche das ein wenig anders. Verständlich, wie gesagt.

Mir ist jedenfalls etwas bewusst geworden. Auf der einen Seite entwickle Open Source Software, bei der ich kommerzielle Verwendung erlaube. Dies tue ich, mit dem Ziel evtl. Anerkennung zu bekommen und meine "Energie" in etwas Praktisches zu stecken. Auf der anderen Seite untersage ich jedoch die kommerzielle Verwendung von meinem Geschreibsel hier auf dem Blog. Dabei würde ich den Wert meiner schriftlichen Ergüsse sogar noch weit unter dem der Software einstufen, ganz zu schweigen von der erheblich geringeren Halbwertszeit meiner Blog-Posts gegenüber meiner Software. Deshalb habe ich meine Lizenz jetzt auf die Creative Commons Attribution 2.0 Lizenz umgestellt, und erlaube damit jetzt auch die kommerzielle Nutzung meiner Inhalte. Nicht, dass das einen meiner zwei Leser interessiern würde.

Dennoch kann ich Kris Argumentation gut nachvollziehen, wenn er von "kooperativer" und "kompetetiver" Wertschöpfung spricht. Ein guter Post für einen hoffentlich guten Schluss.

entry.title: $self->blog->german
entry.summary: Mein erstes deutsches Posting seit einer langen Zeit. Wenn der Begriff "lange Zeit" auf ein Blog, das noch nicht einmal ein halbes Jahr besteht, überhaupt angewendet werden kann. Und ich werde mich auch nicht bei meinem englischen Leser dafür entschuldigen,...
entry.dc:subject: german
entry.content:
Mein erstes deutsches Posting seit einer langen Zeit. Wenn der Begriff "lange Zeit" auf ein Blog, das noch nicht einmal ein halbes Jahr besteht, überhaupt angewendet werden kann. Und ich werde mich auch nicht bei meinem englischen Leser dafür entschuldigen, dass ich auf deutsch schreibe, weil er es sowieso nicht lesen könnte.

Wie auch immer, ich hatte einfach mal wieder Lust, spontan zu schreiben, und mir nicht lange Gedanken über Formulierung und Thema zu machen. Ich frage mich wirklich wie manche Leute es schaffen mehrmals am Tag oder manchmal "nur" täglich seitenlange Posts zu schreiben. Das werde ich wohl nie schaffen, und wenn ich es mir recht überlege, ist eigentlich auch gar nicht mein Ziel. Trotzdem bewundere ich diese Fähigkeiten in gewisser Weise.

Womit wir schon ein wenig beim Thema wären. Vielleicht angeregt durch manche Vor- und Rückschauen, haben ich in den letzten Tagen ein wenig über mein eigenes Schreiben und Bloggen nachgedacht und bin zu dem Schluss gekommen, dass ich einfach ein wenig spontaner werden muss.

Kleinere und häufigere Postings (nicht, dass ich jemals viele lange Posts geschrieben hätte). Mich nicht davor scheuen über Dinge zu schreiben, über die andere schon geschrieben haben, zumindest solange ich "dem Ganzen" etwas Neues hinzufüge, und sei es nur meine Meinung. Und letztlich: Mehr Deutsch!

Auch wenn mein Englisch in Ordnung ist, und ich doch (hoffentlich) recht flüssig schreibe, ist es nunmal nicht meine Muttersprache und auf Englisch schreiben fällt mir doch ein wenig schwerer als auf Deutsch. Meine stark technisch orientierten Posts, werde ich wahrscheinlich weiterhin in englischer Sprache schreiben, weil ich immer noch der Meinung bin, dass der Großteil einer möglichen Interessentengruppe für diese Sachen, englischsprachig ist, aber für meine Ergüsse über andere Themen, werde ich mich hauptsächlich der deutschen Sprache bedienen.

Man könnte also meinen, dass einer meiner Vorsätze für das neue Jahr ist, wobei ich noch nie ernsthaft irgendwelche Vorsätze aufgestellt oder befolgt hätte, mehr zu bloggen und die Kommunikationsmöglichkeiten dieses Mediums besser auszunutzen.

But then you see other people’s goals. And that’s the moment, when the klick happens.
Inspiration. You get reminded of goals you very seldom think of, but that somehow have a special meaning to you.
The marathon goal is such a goal for me. People who know me, will find this totally ridiculous, because I’m not really the sports guy. I’m not totally lazy either, but when it comes to achieving hard, long running goals I could try harder (sometimes).

entry.dc:subject: roosster

Just a short note for your information:
Roosster can be downloaded again. Thanks to the nice and fast folks over at berliOS (the german sourceforge). Visit the Roosster project page to download releases, view tickets/tasks, request features, browse the subversion repository, subscribe to the mailing list and the usual other things.

In case you wonder why I chose to host the project at berliOS instead of sourceforge, the answer is simple. Subversion support! BerliOS supports subversion (as well as good ol' CVS), while sourceforge currently supports only CVS. Although it's planned to provide subversion support in 2005.

That's it for now. Have a nice weekend.

entry.dc:subject: blogging
entry.content:
I converted my MovableType installation (version 3.121) from Berkeley DB to MySQL, for easier backups and faster rebuild times. I ran into some problems, which I wanted to point out. Maybe others will find it useful.

When following Diego's tip to keep both the Berkeley and DBI/MySQL settings in mt.cfg while running mt-db2sql.cgi everything is fine. As long as you don't use nested categories, or subcategories as they are sometimes called. If you happen to use subcategories, the mt-db2sql.cgi script will fail without any meaningful error message.
The solution is simple: Move all your subcategories temporarily to the top-level, while running the conversion script. After the conversion has ended successfully, you can move them back to their previous destination in the category tree.

entry.title: Bloggers should Publish their Bookmarks
entry.summary: A little thought that struck me while surfing around other people's bookmarks on simpy and del.icio.us is learning. Most discussion about social bookmarking I read until now, where all about knowing what other people currently bookmark. But what about...
entry.dc:subject: blogging
entry.content:
A little thought that struck me while surfing around other people's bookmarks on simpy and del.icio.us is learning. Most discussion about social bookmarking I read until now, where all about knowing what other people currently bookmark.
But what about the past bookmarks? Bookmarks are like a small glimpse of people's memory. And if you know the del.icio.us or simpy (insert similar tools here) account of some expert in a field of interest to you, surfing this person's bookmarks is like asking him some (although unspecific) questions.
It's like going up to this expert's house and looking at his bookshelf. A great way of learning, from my point of view.

All this is nothing new, and other people probably have mentioned it already. But it was one use of social bookmarking I hadn't experienced before, and which I find extremely useful.

I think every blogger should publish his or her username at the various social bookmarking platforms.

entry.title: Using HTMLArea with MovableType
entry.summary: Being annoyed with the different kinds of "not-very-powerful-wiki/markup"-syntaxes, I started looking around for free, online WYSIWIG editors that would integrate smoothly with MovableType. So this is my first post that utilizes an online WYSIWIG editor. I'll describe which editors I...
entry.dc:subject: blogging
entry.content:
Being annoyed with the different kinds of "not-very-powerful-wiki/markup"-syntaxes, I started looking around for free, online WYSIWIG editors that would integrate smoothly with MovableType.

So this is my first post that utilizes an online WYSIWIG editor. I'll describe which editors I tried to use, which one I finally chose, how I integrated it into MovableType and finally how well it works. The latter will be subject to change as I write more posts with my chosen editor, and explore the innards of the editor.

The requirements an editor had to fulfill, for me to even consider it, were:

  • A license that lets me use the editor free of charge (I'm not very pedantic about OpenSource licenses).
  • Simple installation (not more than uploading some files and adding some lines of javascript to the file I need the editor on).
  • No serverside component; again, I want to keep it simple.
  • Must work cross-platform, cross-browser (although I currently use only Firefox).
So after some searching I found some editor that fulfilled these requirements and started testing them.
Note: I don't claim these three to be the only online WYSIWYG editors that fit my needs. They simply were the first I found. There are other editors, which may equally well suit my (or your) needs.

FCKeditor

At first I tried FCKeditor (version 2.0 b1). It's licensed under the LGPL, pretty easy to install and very configurable. For example it's easy to define your own set of buttons that make up your toolbar, to adapt the editor to your needs, or even skin the whole editor via an API.
The editor provides the user with possibilities to edit nearly everything. You can even edit the style and id attributes of most elements through the editors interface. So there's almost no need to hand-edit the HTML code, even for advanced users.

But all configurability didn't help me getting it to work properly. The install was a breeze, properly substituting the textareas in question, and showing the toolbar for text formatting. But after some time of editing, popup-windows (mainly the ones, for specifiying the href for a link) didn't close properly and my links got totally messed up. All this, for no apparent reason. And as you might guess: Not being able to use links, can get annoying very fast, when writing blog entries.
Sad but true. It's still too much beta. Maybe I'll try it again, if it's more stable.

Cross-Browser Rich Text Editor

The second editor I tried was the Cross-Browser Rich Text Editor (referred to as RTE from now on). Again, the installation process consists of uploading some files and adding some javascript statements to the right file. But although the online demo and the example, that's bundled with the RTE's distribution, worked perfectly, I couldn't get the editor to work with MovableType, even after nearly an hour of tweaking and poking around. The javascript console showed no errors, and the textarea was displayed, but it showed no toolbar for formatting text entered into the textarea.
So although RTE looked like it would be the simple editor I was looking for, it didn't work for me.

HTMLArea

HTMLArea is the editor I now use. Version 3, which is currently in beta state, supports Mozilla/Firefox, but works flawlessly, as far as I tested it. The installation is easy. Apart from uploading some files, you, again, just have to add some lines of javascript, to the file where you want the editor, and everything is done.
The editor's toolbar is small but still contains everything needed, although it's not as powerful as FCKeditor. It probably is enough for most editing needs and simple enough not to get in the writer's way.
Until now the HTML code HTMLAread produces seems fairly.
As a programmer I miss the capability to format blocks as <code>. But formatting such blocks with Courier works for now, although it's not what you'd call semantic.

MovableType Integration

I used version 3.0RC1 of HTMLArea. As long as the API doesn't change, the instructions should work with newer versions too.
As always: If you are unsure about what you're doing (or worse: Don't know at all what you are doing), make at least a backup of the files you are editing, and read the complete instructions before you start. If you're still unsure, ask someone who knows better.
With MovableType Integration I mean using the WYSIWYG editor for editing blog entries. Therefore it's sufficient to enhance the needed textareas in the file tmpl/cms/edit_entry.tmpl of your MovableType installation. So open up this file in your favorite text editor and add the following lines to the <script> tag at the top of the file, where _editor_url corresponds to the URL where you uploaded the files of the HTMLarea. 

_editor_url = "/htmlarea";
_editor_lang = "en";

Now include the javascript file htmlarea.js into the page. You can do this with something similar to the following. But be sure to change the path to where you uploaded the file (setting of _editor_url above).

<script src="/htmlarea/htmlarea.js" type="text/javascript" />

After you've done this, look for the textareas text and text_more and place the following code after the textarea tags. 

<script type="text/javascript">
var editor1 = new HTMLArea("text");
editor1.generate();

var editor = new HTMLArea("text_more");
editor.generate();
</script>

Save and close the file. Done.
Now log into your MovableType installation and start editing old or new entries. When editing old entries, make sure that the entries were formatted using HTML and that you selected None in the Text Formatter select box.
If you encounter any problems: Read the instructions again!
Of course it's possible to use HTMLArea for more than just the blog editing textareas. But you'll have to figure this out yourself if you need it.

... more

That's it, for my quick and dirty review. Look at this comparison chart to learn of more online WYSIWYG editors, than the ones I mentioned here.

entry.title: Simpy.com - Another Social Bookmark Manager
entry.summary: Some time ago Otis Gospodnetić contacted me in regard to roosster. He told me about his social bookmark manager simpy and of course I had to try it. This is my opinion about it. Basically simpy It's very similar to...
entry.dc:subject: blogging
entry.content:
Some time ago Otis Gospodnetić contacted me in regard to roosster. He told me about his social bookmark manager simpy and of course I had to try it. This is my opinion about it.

Basically simpy It's very similar to del.icio.us, with a slightly more "professional" feel to the UI.

Because of this similarity, and because I assume most people know about del.icio.us, I will directly compare simpy with del.icio.us. I don't do this, to bitch about any of the two, but rather to make easier to understand what simpy does.

Features

  • Both services allow a note, and an arbitrary number of tags/keywords to be associated with a bookmarked page.
    When adding a bookmark, simpy lists the most used tags together with a radio button, so you can easily associate already used tags with a new bookmark. This prevents the usual problem of del.icio.us were you accidently created several tags with similar names. If you bookmark a page with simpy, that was already bookmarked by other simpy users, the service, suggests you the most used keywords by these other users, and provides radio buttons for easy using these tags too (btw this could lead to some interesting evolution or emergence observations).
  • Simpy allows batch importing of your browser's bookmarks, and similarly exports pages bookmarked via simpy as a browser's bookmarks file. Though it's odd, that the import supports Mozilla/Firefox, IE, Safari and Opera, while the export only supports Mozilla/Firefox and IE.
    This import/export can (or could) be done in del.icio.us too, although with the help of 3rd party tools, that use the del.icio.us API. Slight advantage for simpy.
  • Simpy sports a Bookmarklet for easy bookmarking of pages. Also there's a special Mozilla/Firefox Sidebar-page, which gives you access to frequently used functions of simpy.
    There are already a lot of Bookmarkelets/Extensions that speed up working with del.icio.us, so in this area it's a tie.
  • Being developed by a Lucene-guru (Otis wrote Lucene in Action together with Erik Hatcher and is the maintainer of the jGuru.com Lucene FAQ), you bet that simpy has some nifty search features. And it has. You can either search your own bookmarks, or all user's bookmarks, Your search can be refined by adding/removing keywords/tags to your query, similar to chaining tags at del.icio.us. The search is fast and supports many (if not all, haven't tested them) of Lucene's Query Syntax, which is a lot more than what del.icio.us has to offer. Although it may be that not many people actually use complex queries on their bookmarks. Anyways, one point for simpy.
  • Simpy has no API (yet). Acccording to Otis, this will be included in a December's release. Therefore, hacking cool tools for simpy like it's done for del.icio.us (see cocoalicious, btw people should be #$%&* when they create such obscure names) is not possible. Advantage for del.icio.us.
  • Both services claim to allow social bookmarking. I won't go into detail how I understand the term social bookmarking (others have done this before and better).
    The social component in simpy is called Topics. It's quite powerful but takes some time getting used to. Topics allow you to group certain users/sbscription into groups and filter them to your liking. Of course you can browse tags too, similar to del.icio.us. Which brings us to del.icio.us' social component. Which is based on tagging. You tag bookmark with a certain keyword, other people might use the same keyword, and will find you and your bookmarks (of course there's a little more to it, but for the sake of comparison I keep it simple).
    Despite the higher learning curve, I'd say that the social component of simpy is far more advanced than del.icio.us. One more point for simpy.

Simp(l)y not good ...

Although stated as a core feature and advertised prominently on the simpy.com home page, I think the full text search of the bookmarked pages' content either doesn't work, or doesn't work well enough to be usable. The latest release notes it says, that full text searching was suspended for a while but works again.
Nonetheless I tried several times to find bookmarked pages through searching with meaningful keywords, which existed in the pages' content, but the search never resulted in finding the pages.

Conclusion

Apart from the the mentioned caveat and some very minor issues (like the words tag and keyword being used interchangeably or the top keywords not being sorted alphabetically, which is what I would expect of such a listing) simpy is a nice service, which goes beyond the "basic" set of features implemented by del.icio.us. I use it on a daily basis, and will keep doing so, until roosster is in a more usable state.

Sidenote

While surfing around simpy for writing this post I discovered spurl, which seems (again) very similar to simpy and del.icio.us. But I won't look at it further, as my appetite for social bookmarking is satisfied for now. Maybe someone will write a review and tell me about it, or maybe there is already a review, as spurl seems to be around longer than simpy and del.icio.us (not sure about that).

entry.title: Did Someone Ask for Personal Search
entry.summary: Simply amazing what Firefox/Mozilla extensions are out there. I just found Scrapbook and it's almost all my archiving/searching/finding dreams come true. Scrapbook is all about capturing web pages. You can either capture a whole page, or just a selected portion...
entry.dc:subject: blogging
entry.content:
Simply amazing what Firefox/Mozilla extensions are out there. I just found Scrapbook and it's almost all my archiving/searching/finding dreams come true.

Scrapbook is all about capturing web pages. You can either capture a whole page, or just a selected portion of a web page. You can tell Srapbook to capture .mp3, image, movie, sound and archive files with a captured page. Scrapbook can even follow all links on a captured page and save them too. You can attach notes to captured pages (almost a killer feature for me, that I miss in so many applications: Note-taking) and sort captured pages into folders, although folders aren't hierarchical. But since I use Bloglines, I don't think hierarchical categories are really necessary.

And like that wasn't enough, Scrapbook features a fulltext search over all your captured pages, including the notes attached to the pages. The search result display isn't the nicest thing in the world, but it's fulltext.

Great Product. Go test it!

Via: pixelgangster

Update: After using it for sometime, it bugs the hell out of me, that the index of captured pages is bound to the local computer. Sad but true, this is a killer argument for me.

entry.dc:subject: blogging
entry.content:
Here I am, covered up in work, but I still can't keep my hands off my newsreader. Because I want to share some ideas and notes, and don't have the time to write full fledged entries, I'll post only some short notes for now. Maybe I'll do a follow up on some of them later:

Need for Roosster

Via Greg Scher I learned of wetaste.com. It's interesting to see that I'm not alone with my braindeadness, and other people need some kind of personal web archive too. Meanwhile, the second release of Roosster, which will include a web interface via a (optionally embedded) web server, is advancing. Slowly, but it's moving. Maybe I'll find some more time in the next weeks. I'll definitely have more free time then. We'll see if I will spend it on Roosster.

Not Fat, Not Thick, Just Slim

Joe Gregorio, author of the AtomAPI spec, talks about how Gmail and OddPost seem to create a new kind of UI category. Both provide an UI, that's far more than just HTML, and still less than the usual ''thick'' clients (like Java Applets). That in itself is nothing new, but I think the programmer's perspective on this is interesting. I see more and more frameworks (ActiveMQ, Pustefix just for a start), that provide means to implement this new kind of web UI by using streaming of data and intelligent use of different kinds of javascript wizardry.

Telling your Boss about Blogs

Jeremy asked an interesting question, and many people responded. I'm interested what Jeremy himself has to say about it.

Google buys Microsoft?

Adam Rifkin asks, if Google should buy Microsoft, to finally buy a company, that contributes revenue instead of ''just'' adding to the pile of cool technology owned by Google.

entry.title: Why is 'Desktop Search != Web Search'
entry.summary: Reading Kevin Burton's announcement about a Lucene-based Desktop search application I wondered (for the n-th time), why people who develop Desktop Search applications (be it open source groups or companies) take this separation between Desktop and the Web so serious?...
entry.dc:subject: roosster
entry.content:
Reading Kevin Burton's announcement about a Lucene-based Desktop search application I wondered (for the n-th time), why people who develop Desktop Search applications (be it open source groups or companies) take this separation between Desktop and the Web so serious?

If you have a search application for indexing, searching you local computer, why not extend this application and let the user add items from the web to the index?

Maybe I'm just not good enough at forming Google queries. But I've had several experiences already, where I vaguely remembered something (a post by someone else, a solved problem etc.) and couldn't find it again using Google (or the likes). Sometimes The Index is too large. For me at least. Searching for some very specific piece of information would certainly be more effective, if the queried index contained only 10.000 or even 100.000 entries instead of 4.285.199.774 or even more.

Sure, I can save the page and then let the search application index it, but that's only half the picture and wouldn't be very usable in my opinion.

Diametrically opposed to Ben's Context Specific Mirroring Idea, I want all the things I somehow publish on the net, not just this blog or the Wiki, to be available in my very own search index, to "come back to me". Why not achieve this using a Desktop Search application? Why not give the application an URL of an RSS/Atom feed and the contained entries? Importing your del.icio.us links into your personal knowledge index? Cool, I say.

In my opinion, Desktop Search Applications, or Personal Search Engines, as I prefer to call them, should provide you with search capabilities over all the information that's personally relevant to you. Whether this information lives on your local computer's hard drive or somewhere on the web.

Implementing such a thing into an existing search application wouldn't be hard. I know this, because I'm implementing it right now in Roosster. Until the separation of Desktop and "selective" Web Search has faded from Desktop Search applications, I will have to stick to Roosster.
